description.plain:
“Do It” is the second single from sister duo Chloe x Halle’s second studio album Ungodly Hour.

The track has an upbeat sound while simultaneously maintaining its cool R&B influences and breakdowns. It gives a lighthearted message to listeners about having fun doing you and enjoying it with your friends by your side.

The overall look and style of the song art as well as the music video aesthetic is new for the duo. Chloe x Halle have evolved stylistically and are exploring new ways and styles of expressing their artistry through their music.

The sisters also created a fun TikTok dance challenge to go along with the single, which fans from all over the world have happily and creatively participated in.

https://twitter.com/chloexhalle/status/1261732809825153024?s=20

description.plain:
Chloe x Halle team up with English duo Disclosure for “Ungodly Hour,” the album’s title track. Speaking with Pop Sugar in January 2020, the Atlanta natives elaborated on the collaboration and how their session with Disclosure sparked the song’s title:

[Disclosure] are two brothers, and they’re literally like mirrors of [Chloe x Halle]. [Ungodly Hour] was a phrase for that [studio session] riff. We kind of spoke it into existence, you could say.

The interview also revealed an alternate title idea from the session was “The Trouble With Angels.”

description.plain:
“Forgive Me” is the second track of Ungodly Hour. It is led into by the album’s signature message:

Don’t ever ask for permission, ask for forgiveness.

The song drives the message of being completely unapologetic in who you are and feeling self-empowered, regardless of who accepts or rejects it. Knowing that you never have to apologize or feel “teary” over what another person perceives you to be or how another person chooses to treat you. Recognizing that those perceptions are simply a reflection of their energy alone and have nothing to do with your own.

As Chloe states in an interview with Apple Music:

Forgive me for not caring and giving you that energy to control me and make me sad.”

Chloe x Halle deliver this message with a strong, fierce and unapologetic demeanor through their vocals, and throughout the dark yet vibrant music video. While embodying this fierce attitude the sisters also embody a calming and sophisticated demeanor. This can be tied into the song’s message of being completely unapologetic and unphased.

As Chloe x Halle’s energy remains solid they continue to move forward in their power, no permission is asked, no forgiveness is needed, and not a tear is shed.

“Forgive Me” is the second track of Ungodly Hour. It is led into by the album’s signature message:

Don’t ever ask for permission, ask for forgiveness.

The song drives the message of being completely unapologetic in who you are and feeling self-empowered, regardless of who accepts or rejects it. Knowing that you never have to apologize or feel “teary” over what another person perceives you to be or how another person chooses to treat you. Recognizing that those perceptions are simply a reflection of their energy alone and have nothing to do with your own.

As Chloe states in an interview with Apple Music:

Forgive me for not caring and giving you that energy to control me and make me sad.”

Chloe x Halle deliver this message with a strong, fierce and unapologetic demeanor through their vocals, and throughout the dark yet vibrant music video. While embodying this fierce attitude the sisters also embody a calming and sophisticated demeanor. This can be tied into the song’s message of being completely unapologetic and unphased.

annotations:
Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
 Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
 Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
 Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
 Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
 Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
 Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
 Lie-lie-lie-lie-lie
Chloe closes out the song by repeating ‘lie’ as if she was covering her ears and saying la la la in order to drown out having to hear anymore of his lies.

Feel like I’m high up, yeah
 I’m too high up
 I’ll let the light light up

The intro of “Forgive Me” was stated to be ‘gibberish’ by Halle Bailey herself during the duo’s November 12 Instagram Live:

Nothing, at the beginning of “Forgive Me” it’s literally gibberish. I remember going into the booth and just doing that, and I think the only thing we got out of that take was that intro and then the hook melody.

[posted by cxhnow on youtube]
timestamp: 2:27
https://youtu.be/3H8_Sh-Ugq4

So forgive me, forgive me
 I been goin’ too hard in your city

The phrase “been goin’ too hard in your city” can be interpreted in 2 ways, the first being in a literal sense:

In spite of the situation, the girls don’t feel it’s necessary to hide away and make things easier for the person who has wronged them. They are truly unbothered and do not care how uncomfortable it might make their former flames feel.

Another interpretation could be in a metaphorical sense:

“Your city” could simply refer to ones entity; their very existence, thoughts and emotions. To go “too hard” in someone’s city might mean to constantly be on their mind and in their thoughts. Therefore, Chloe and Halle are all this boy can think about.

Movin’ too fast, now you caught in the middle
 Try so hard to keep up, now you single

When speaking about the meaning of “Forgive Me” with Apple Music, Chloe said:

I was going through a situation where I was dealing with a guy and he picked someone else over me, and it really bothered me because I felt like it wasn’t done in the most honest light. I like to be told things upfront.

Therefore this verse could be interpreted as Chloe’s telling of events, the boy she was speaking to spent too long going back and forth between her and another girl; to the point of exhaustion. He was unable to pick one girl and ultimately lost both in the end.
Why you wanna plead the fifth?

“Pleading the fifth” refers to the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution. One of the clauses of the Fifth Amendment says that people have a right to decline to answer questions if their answer could incriminate them, and “pleading the fifth” means that you’re choosing to stay silent. So if someone “pleads the fifth,” they could be a little suspicious.

Given that the outro says that they catch him every time he lies, it doesn’t really matter if the subject pleads the fifth or not!
No one’s hittin’ you on the loop, on replay

Although it hasn’t been confirmed, this line could be a reference to Chloe x Halle’s song “Drop” which can be found on their debut album “The Kids Are Alright” but was first dropped on their 2016 EP, “Sugar Symphony”.

The song discusses a person who the girls can’t get out of their head like a good song, but at the same time know they shouldn’t be listening to on repeat.

A snippet of the lyrics read,
“Baby, I ain’t listening, listening, listening
You drive me so crazy, so crazy, so crazy
Boy can you please play that again
You know you’re not what I wanna sing
But you’re the only thing, only thing
That’s playing in my head”

In strong contrast here as the girls have evolved and grown as artists and individuals, they share the message of not needing to stress over this type of person any longer. They recognize that no one has the time or energy to give to someone who puts their energy off balance. They don’t deserve the hit, the loop, or the replay.

description.plain:
“Tipsy” serves as the fifth track off of Chloe x Halle’s second studio album Ungodly Hour.

In this song, Chloe and Halle are illustrating being intoxicated by their lovers but if they do anything to break their hearts, they would break their lovers' hearts right back.

This song exaggerates that concept by warning their significant others that they would kill them if they make a wrong move. The word “tipsy” can also act as a double entendre, saying that they love the feeling of being in love but being drunk can also lead to impulsive and emotion-led decisions, such as murder.

song.title: Tipsy

album.full_title: Ungodly Hour by Chloe x Halle
album.name: Ungodly Hour

body.plain:
“Tipsy” serves as the fifth track off of Chloe x Halle’s second studio album Ungodly Hour.

In this song, Chloe and Halle are illustrating being intoxicated by their lovers but if they do anything to break their hearts, they would break their lovers' hearts right back.

This song exaggerates that concept by warning their significant others that they would kill them if they make a wrong move. The word “tipsy” can also act as a double entendre, saying that they love the feeling of being in love but being drunk can also lead to impulsive and emotion-led decisions, such as murder.

songs.full_title: Tipsy (Spotify Singles) by Chloe x Halle
songs.title: Tipsy (Spotify Singles)

annotations: Better than those other guys who change up like the weather, yeah
She is encouraging her love interest to treat her better than any former guy she’ve dealt with.

I might be a little tipsy on your love
 Makes me a little crazy, but so what?

Most who’ve been in love can relate to the feeling of being drunk in love. Being drunk in love is a feeling almost impossible to describe, yet so many of us have felt it. It’s that giddiness you feel after a date. It’s the butterflies in your stomach when you’re with them. It’s the rose-colored glasses you see them through. They are so perfect to you. You can see their flaws but those are perfect, too. You’re suddenly walking around in a daze with blurred vision from utter happiness.

I’ll hit you where it hurts, yeah
 If you don’t put me first, yeah
Chloe and Halle is warning their lovers to put them first or they will harm them where it’ll hurt.
Oh, I wonder how I accidentally put them in the ground, yeah
Chloe and Halle are going to act confused on how they accidentally murdered their lovers – putting them into the ground if they ever get caught.

You’re strumming on my heartstrings, don’t be dumb
 If you love your little life, then don’t fuck up

To strum/strumming, means to play an instrument that has strings (like a guitar) by sweeping your fingers/thumb or a plectrum up and down across the strings to make a sound on the instrument.

“You’re strumming on my heart strings” meaning that the significant other is making Halle (or Chloe) feel some type of way (most likely a good way) at how the significant other is making them feel by playing with their heart/emotion. This is a metaphor since they’ve described their heart as if it’s a guitar (hence the “ on my heart strings” part).

“If you love your little life, then don’t fuck up” meaning If this significant other value the good things in their life and how thing are going for them, it’s suggested that they shouldn’t mess up whatever that’s going on between them and one of the girls and don’t mistreat or use their heart incorrectly or you’ll figuratively be “dead/done"

description.plain:
On “Busy Boy”, Chloe & Halle sing about a man who’s actively with other women, and their awareness of his activities.

A rumor started going around about who the song was about. At the front of the rumor was Diggy Simmons, Chloe x Halle’s grown-ish co-star. Chloe and Diggy do play a couple on the show, and dated in real life. When asked about if Diggy was the subject of the song in an interview, Chloe responded:

What I love about creating music is that we can kind of just put our experiences in the music, and that’s how we share our personal lives. And it’s fun because our fans can kind of see what we’ve been dealing with. Yeah."

annotatable.link_title: Busy Boy by Chloe x Halle
annotatable.title: Busy Boy

body.plain:
On “Busy Boy”, Chloe & Halle sing about a man who’s actively with other women, and their awareness of his activities.

A rumor started going around about who the song was about. At the front of the rumor was Diggy Simmons, Chloe x Halle’s grown-ish co-star. Chloe and Diggy do play a couple on the show, and dated in real life. When asked about if Diggy was the subject of the song in an interview, Chloe responded:

What I love about creating music is that we can kind of just put our experiences in the music, and that’s how we share our personal lives. And it’s fun because our fans can kind of see what we’ve been dealing with. Yeah."

annotations:
That’s why the nice guys, they will always last
 That’s why the playboys always finish fast

Chloe x Halle invert the common phrase “nice guys always finish last,” which is usually taken to mean that nice men don’t do well in the dating context. It’s a misogynistic trope suggesting that men should treat women poorly to have better dating prospects. Interestingly, a version of the line was first uttered by Brooklyn Dodgers manager Leo Durocher to describe nice guys in the baseball context.

Here, they say the opposite is true: nice guys can have more successful, long-term relationships, while playboys are just for passing flings.

It’s four o’clock
 You sendin’ me too many pictures of your... (Oh)

Ungodly Hour sees both Chloe and Halle introduce much more audacious sides of themselves, displaying material much bolder than their first two projects.

This line in particular stands out from their earlier songwriting and personalities, with the sisters insinuating the word “cock” at the end. Up until now, the sisters had avoided using swear words in lyrics and interviews, even omitting them in their cover of Kendrick Lamar’s “HUMBLE.”

A June 2020 USA Today article quotes the sisters admitting that it took their parents a few listens to “Busy Boy” to come around to the newer material:

Dad would be like, “What?” Mom would be like, “Oh, really?” Dad would listen to the song a few more times and be like, “OK, I like it.” He said, “I just had to get over what you guys were saying.” We all started laughing around the house.

body.plain: “80/20” is one of two additional songs on the Ungodly Hour (Chrome Edition) album. The sisters first played a snippet for their fans on Instagram Live on June 18, 2020.

annotations:
I’m a good girl but you make me bad
 Got a real one, but I do him bad
 I’m a good girl but you make me bad
 Got a real one, but I do him bad
This part of the track was first shown on an Instagram live (19.6.20) by the duo where Chloe stated this was her favourite part

I got that eighty-twenty, know I got that eighty-twenty
 I get that eighty from my baby, and it’s good for me (Oh)
 But I want that twenty-twenty, thinking ’bout that twenty-twenty (Twenty, twenty-twenty, baby)
 I get that eighty from my baby, do it, do it for me (Oh, oh-oh, oh)

Chlöe and Halle sing about being torn between two people. The relationship she’s in is mostly fulfilling (80%), it’s still missing that extra 20%… which the side-piece provides. It’s a best-of-both-worlds situation.



This is also a reference to a dietary practice where 80% of the time you eat healthy, and 20% of the time you indulge in junk food. She gets that 80 from her man (substance), but she still wants to indulge in that 20. It’s also called a weekend diet, which may be a SZA cross-reference
